11:11 am
BE11:11am

Broad view first.

BE11:11am

In our view, the fragmented election result has opened up the nomination
nprocess for the EU Presidencies as the Liberals and Greens are in a position to leverage their required support. Heads of state will meet on May 28 to start the nomination process. We expect more clarity about nominations at the June 20-21 Council meeting but see risks of a lengthier nomination and subsequent appointment process.

OnYourRight Morning all
BE11:12am

Preliminary results indicate that in line with expectations and more polarized electorates, right wing Eurosceptic parties did well in the elections but perhaps less well than widely expected, remaining well short of a majority with around 23% of seats shared between three Eurosceptic parties, the European Conservatives and Reformists Group (ECR), Europe of Nations and Freedom Group (ENF) and Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy Group (EFDD). The UK’s Brexit Party contributes around 4% of Eurosceptic MEPs, leading us to expect Eurosceptic MEPs to make up around 20% of the EP if and when Brexit takes effect. And while notably, Eurosceptic populist parties became the largest parties in France, Italy, Poland and Hungary, they underperformed polls in for example Germany, The Netherlands and Spain.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The usual reconfigurations of European political groups we see after elections could increase the size of populist factions, but we would expect not by more than 20 seats or an increase of around 3% of seats. In Particular, Hungary’s Eurosceptic Fidezs party that won 53% of the Hungarian vote (13 seats for the EPP) could end up leaving the EPP in light of its current suspension to join the populist European Alliance for People and Nations (EAPN), led by Italian Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini.2
In the current aftermath of the elections, we are seeing a renewed push by Eurosceptic leaders to unite populist parties in a more influential group. We remain of the view that populist groups will remain obstructionist rather than set the European agenda. By definition, domestically focused populists pursue a national agenda at odds with cross-border coalition-building at the European level. It will thus be difficult for the Eurosceptic parties to form a cohesive group to leverage their numbers because of their large respective differences. Also, falling well short of a majority, to set the agenda populist groups would need to find a willing coalition party which seems unlikely at this point. That said, the more divided coalition will provide them with more opportunities to disrupt the legislative process as majorities will be more difficult to find with the fragmented coalition and resulting larger coalition.

BE11:13am

And JPM

nightingale20201 Morning all
BE11:13am

The EU elections are important for a number of reasons. At the EU level, they have revealed the level of
populist support and will now kick-start the appointments for top EU jobs (incl. the ECB presidency). At the
national level, the EU elections have already acted as a trigger for changes in leadership and snap general
elections. An informal dinner of the European Council tomorrow night should provide early indications on the
top EU jobs, while other implications of the election are mostly in terms of national politics at this stage.
Populist support has increased
In terms of the level of populist support, our classification gives 211 seats to populist parties (28% of the total),
which is around 10 seats less than suggested by the polls but up from 168 seats (22% of the total) at the last
election in 2014. Populist parties that are left-wing did not make any real gains: they won around 40 seats,
which was fewer than predicted by the polls and in line with the 2014 outturn. Populist parties that are rightwing
won around 170 seats, which is in line with the polls and up from 123 seats at the last election.
The right-wing populists would be the largest single parliamentary grouping if they all worked together and if
Hungary’s Fidesz left the main centre-right EPP to join them. In that case, they could try to claim the presidency
of the European Parliament through the Spitzenkandidaten process. But, Fidesz has made clear that it will
remain in the EPP and the other right-wing populists are spread across a number of other groupings.
Despite gains in the number of seats, populists will not be able to change the direction of Europe for two
reasons. First, even if they have the numbers, they are unlikely to be able to form a single parliamentary
grouping. Hence, the European Parliament is still likely to be run by centrist parties, even if coalition-building
will be a bit more difficult. And second, although the European Parliament is powerful, it does not set the
agenda for Europe. Agenda setting is really done by the European Commission and the European Council.

BE11:15am

And SocGen.

BE11:15am

The results of the European elections were broadly in line with expectations, but with two
key surprises. First, voter turnout at 51% was much higher than in previous elections.
Second, the Greens achieved a much higher score than five years ago, beating most of
the polls. Adding in the Liberals’ good score, the pro-integration parties now have just
under a quarter of the seats compared to a bare 15% in 2014.
The message seems clear: EU voters do not want less Europe, but perhaps a greener one.
As such climate change could well be one of the key priorities of the next Commission.
Despite these surprises, the political groups fared much as expected: the right-wing European
People’s Party (EPP) remains the largest group, followed by the Socialists and Democrats
(S&D) and the Liberals (ALDE). The EPP-S&D duopoly has been broken and an agreement
with a third party – either the Liberals or the Greens, or most likely both – will be needed for
an absolute majority.
By country, the results were also broadly as expected. In Italy, Five Star performed poorly,
dropping below 20%, while the League came in above 30%. This clearly increases the
prospect of a government coalition break-up and new elections before year-end. In Germany,
risks for the ruling “grand coalition” have also increased given the SPD’s poor result, but the
likelihood of any change in the near future looks low. In France, Marine Le Pen’s far-right
party came first, but only narrowly beating Macron’s centrist grouping, and as such we think
this should not have major consequences for Macron’s leadership or his reform agenda.

BE11:17am

There remains no majority in Parliament for a “no deal” Brexit, and we believe the EU-27 is unlikely to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement because of a change in personnel. Our central view remains that the new Prime Minister — notwithstanding the initial rhetoric — will eventually return to the House of Commons with a close variant of the current Withdrawal Agreement. Our updated subjective probabilities are 45% for a close variant of the current deal (down from 50%), 40% for “no Brexit” and 15% for “no deal” (up from 10%).

BE11:24am

Bovis has announced that it recently made a proposal to combine Bovis Homes and Galliford Try's Linden Homes and Partnership & Regeneration business for a consideration of £950m together with the assumption of Gallifords' private placement debt of £100m via the issuance of new Bovis Homes shares to Galliford Try shareholders. It was envisaged that Galliford Try (GFRD-LSE, Hold, 710p target) would remain a UK listed Construction focused group. The Board of Galliford Try rejected the proposal as it was not considered in the interests of shareholders. Bovis Homes and Galliford Try are no longer in discussions.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

That's what's happened. And here's Canaccord to say it's probably the end of the story.

OnYourRight @AMALtd @Red I suspect the Brexit Party doesn't know (yet) what they want as a mandate. There are purely reactionary (a bit like Trump).
BE11:25am

This is essentially a reversal of the situation back in early 2017, when the then
struggling Bovis was subject to a merger proposal from Galliford Try (and also one from
Redrow). From Bovis Homes' standpoint, we can see the strategic logic of the proposed
combination. It would immediately increase the scale of its housing business (Bovis & Linden Homes would deliver c.7,000 to 8,000 units) and would likely deliver some synergies. It would also accelerate the Group's strategy of widening its offering to other forms of housing tenure as it gained a strong foothold in the attractive and fast growing Partnerships and Regeneration business. Obviously, Greg Fitzgerald the current CEO of Bovis was the former CEO of Galliford Try and therefore should know the business well. Importantly, an all-share deal would avoid gearing up the balance sheet of Bovis Homes

and thereby maintain a conservative level of financial risk. It would also not burden Bovis with the less attractive Construction business.
It arguably makes less strategic sense for Galliford Try as it would leave it focused on an unloved and less attractive UK contracting sub-sector with questions relating to what the balance sheet would then look like. The key issue for Galliford shareholders would be one of price and being able to instantly crystalise the inherent value of the Housing business within the Group, against taking the risk of waiting for value to be realised over time within the current Galliford Try group.
Clearly, Bovis could come back with a revised offer (offer a cash element and/or increase its offer) that is agreeable to both parties, but we do not see this deal as a foregone conclusion. It is worth remembering that the approaches made to Bovis in 2017 faded into nothing. This situation does highlight the progress that Bovis has made over the last few years with its turnaround and its renewed level of confidence as well as highlighting the potential value within Galliford Try shares that current management will arguably now be under increased pressure to deliver. We would not expect this to lead to a wave of consolidation in the wider sector, and see it as being very Galliford Try/Bovis Homes specific.

Gary Geezer I'll bite, why is Intu down? Assume there's a note
BE11:26am

As at the last financial year end, the total amount invested in Linden Homes and Partnership & Regeneration was c.£892m, implying a c.1.17 times historic multiple based on the Bovis proposal. Based on our forecasts for FY2019E, the proposed consideration equates to an EV:EBITA forward multiple of c.5.25 times. These multiples arguably look attractive for Bovis shareholders given the sector average multiples. Bovis Homes currently trades on a 2019E P/NAV multiple of c.1.25 times and a PE of c. 9 times.

Based on Galliford Try's disclosed CY18 financials, we calculate an implied multiple of 1.36x EV/IC (excluding intangible assets) or 1.42x P/TNAV and 5.1x EV/EBIT. This compares to Bovis' own trailing trading multiple of 6.9x EV/EBIT and 1.27x P/TNAV. Although exact terms were not disclosed, we estimate the deal would have implied Bovis shareholders holding 58% of the combined entity and Galliford Try owning 42%, assuming Bovis' last share price of 995p (24 May).

While investors may question the wiseness of the deal given where we are in the housing cycle and political uncertainty, Bovis indicates the acquisition was targeted due to the fit of the business in housebuilding, the scale it would bring to the group as a whole, and the inclusion of the Partnerships business in its own emerging new division. However, Bovis management indicate this is not the start of an acquisition strategy for the group, more that there was an opportunity presented due to the mix of the business at Galliford and its valuation (we calculate the deal would have been 10-15% enhancing to Bovis EPS). Bovis management are keen to highlight that the fact an acquisition was considered should be taken as a sign of confidence in how its own strategy is progressing.

BE11:40am

The short interest is up to 17.4% of the float at 24 May, and the implied EPS downgrades on higher below-the-line charges should add weight to bears’ arguments. For the bulls, that the JV is complete will support the idea that NMC can lead the consolidation of the Saudi healthcare market.

A. M. @red: meanwhile, they have been causing damage to urban transport systems.
BE11:41am

NMC/GOSI shareholding in JV is 53/47%, with NMC contributing its five
assets in Saudi plus $66m (SAR250m) and GOSI adding its 17.4m (38.88% of total) share interest in National Medical Care at SAR54/share (3% premium to the current share price). The JV then used the cash-on-hand to acquire a further 4.6m shares in private transactions (SAR242m at SAR52.60, ~24.5x one-year forward cons PE or ~11.5x one-year forward cons EV/EBITDA), taking the JV’s total interest in Care to 22m shares or a 49.2% stake. The final structure comes almost a year after NMC first announced intention to form a JV with GOSI in June ’18.
NMC’s returns in Saudi are not stellar thus far – NMC’s value contribution was $286m to the JV and $253m from GOSI. Prior to the $66m cash allocated to the JV, NMC had spent ~$200m on M&A and capex in Saudi, with the first transactions announced in August ‘16. Subtracting the $66m from $286m shows NMC has achieved a ~$20m or 10% valuation uplift on Saudi investments since entering. Considering the macro backdrop and performance of listed Saudi healthcare names, we do not put much emphasis in the valuation uplift, though we expect the bears would argue this is a sign of ineffective capital allocation.

BE11:44am

The JV is good news for NMC and should provide relief for investors accordingly – the deal has closed, the terms look largely as expected, the investment thus far limited and small guidance upgrade is welcome. Furthermore, adding net income guidance should be taken well by the market, as it demonstrates the company’s further willingness to improve communications while giving investors greater visibility. In our view, this JV is not about the impact today but about the long-term opportunity that the Saudi market offers, so we eagerly await the conference call, when we expect questions to centre on the company’s future expansionary plans and the levels of investment required to achieve them. Overall, we expect the shares to react positively today to the enhanced clarity and the big step forward in the KSA story.

red the xmas parties at bookham were legendary i heard
BE11:51am

"After careful review of the terms of FCA’s friendly proposal", Renault "decided to study with interest the opportunity" and plans to issue "further communication in due course".

BE11:52am

Makes sense, says UBS.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

There is a substantial product and platform overlap in Europe. RNO would (1) help FCA to achieve CO2 compliance in the EU at much lower cost than on a stand-alone basis and (2) bring strong market presence (#1) in Russia (where FCA pulled out a few years ago). FCA would bring (1) a strong and profitable US pick-up and SUV business (although RNO has never expressed strong interest in gaining direct exposure) and (2) a strong position in South America. A deal would not solve the overall lack of exposure in China. It remains to be seen how Renault’s key shareholders respond to the approach, particularly the French state and Nissan, who are Renault’s largest shareholders with a 15% stake each [but Nissan without voting rights]. According to AutoNews, the French state would support a merger while Nissan has not been involved in the discussion.

BE11:53am

In order to achieve a 50/50 ownership, FCA proposes a €1.60/share equalizing dividend to be paid before the merger and an exchange ratio of 5.328x, which would result in a value of €55.23 per Renault share including the €3.55 DPS proposed by the Renault board, or equivalent to a c10% premium to Friday's close. In a merger of equals, half of the envisaged ~€5bn pre-tax synergies (ie, ~€2.5bn pre-tax or ~€1.75bn after tax) would benefit RNO shareholders. We estimate that capitalizing the synergies with 3-5x PE would boost RNO's valuation by up to €5.25-8.75bn or ~€19-31/share. RNO's share price has "only" been up by €6/share, reflecting implementation costs and execution risk, as well as the aspect that it could take several years to implement platform and plant synergies. Post the FCA proposed merger, the stub of Renault re-rated from €13 to €20, but it is still trading on depressed multiples with an EV/Sales of 5% and EV/adj. EBIT of 1.7x (excluding synergies).

red does it not seem like a technology transfer from nissan to renault and now to fiat?
BE11:54am

or, if you prefer, from the FCA side.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Even though we cannot assess the likelihood of a full merger of the two, we think the potential for synergies is obvious. There is a substantial product and platform overlap in Europe. Also, Renault is much more advanced in electrified cars than FCA, which would help FCA to achieve CO2 compliance in the EU at much lower cost than on a stand-alone basis. FCA brings a strong and profitable US pick-up and SUV business to the table, a region in which Renault is only indirectly present through its Nissan shareholding. In our recent merger scenario report for a combination between FCA and PSA, we derived potential synergies between €3-6.6bn mainly in Europe, and we think the synergy potential with Renault would be within a similar range. However, FCA said there would not be any plant closures in the case of a merger with Renault. It remains to be seen how Renault’s key shareholders respond to the approach, particularly the French state and Nissan, who are Renault’s largest shareholders with a 15% stake each [but Nissan without voting rights].

Tom Dalgleish @Red and a style transfer the other way
BE11:55am

And MOST.

BE11:55am

We think there are many potential benefits to all parties from a proposed merger: 1 - EV/ AV technology sharing - as we have highlighted, the investment hurdle of new autos technologies is too huge for many smaller OEMs; sharing this can help OEMs achieve considerable investment savings, in our view (and there could conceivably be many more deals in the industry); 2 - European emissions - 2021, 2025, and 2030 European CO2 emissions legislation is very onerous for existing OEMs, and may prove very tough to achieve, leading to potentially very large penalties for missing fleet average CO2 targets. On this basis, FCA has recently agreed to pay Tesla over $2bn to pool their European CO2 fleet averages; 3 - European consolidation - after the exit from Europe by GM, there could be more room for consolidation in Europe. Combining Renault, FCA, Dacia brands in Europe, with overlapping LCV businesses could bring very substantial platform and drivetrain synergies to the combined group - allowing both Renault and FCA margin improvement - even without job losses; 4 - Latin American business overlap is significant with Renault's strong Argentinian position added to Fiat's Brazil market share to bring real economies of scale to improve Lat Am returns; 5 - RCI Banque could finance group vehicle sales - RCI Banque has grown strongly in assets and EBIT in recent years but could also feasibly finance FCA group sales in a combined entity, allowing it to potentially double in size again - creating a large, less cyclical profit stream to the combined group.

Wide sector implications for this potential deal
Both Renault’s and FCA’s share prices reacted positively to FCA’s proposal,
while Peugeot shares were down, as a deal is now less likely and the
positioning of both played against it. We retain our Buy on all three stocks,
notably as a potential Renault-FCA deal would likely support a sustained
positive pricing environment in Europe. Suppliers’ stock prices reacted
positively, despite the negative implications of further consolidation,
probably as the SXAP has largely underperformed over the last month.
